title: 113_hr4756
content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The BRAVE Act amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying, mandating local educational agencies to report bullying incidents within 7 business days. Employees must describe the bullying acts, any reference to protected characteristics, and the agency's response. The BRAVE Act amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying incidents, mandating local educational agencies to report within 7 business days. Employees must report bullying acts, mention of protected characteristics, and the agency's response. An exception allows employees not to report bullying if the student requests confidentiality. A designated individual receives reports of bullying within the agency. The BRAVE Act requires local educational agencies to designate an individual to receive reports of bullying and inform all employees of the contact information. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform employees of the bullying acts and the agency's response, excluding any personally identifiable information. Additionally, agencies must publish quarterly reports on bullying incidents. The BRAVE Act mandates local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and responses by agency employees, excluding any personally identifiable student information. The BRAVE Act requires local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports on bullying incidents, ensuring no personally identifiable student information is included. Additionally, agencies must conduct an annual review of bullying policies. Federal funding is contingent on compliance with these requirements. The BRAVE Act mandates local educational agencies to review bullying policies annually and certify compliance to receive federal funding. The Office of Civil Rights establishes a procedure for students to file complaints regarding bullying incidents. The Assistant Secretary of the Office of Civil Rights for the Department of Education will establish a procedure for complaints related to non-compliance with bullying policies and investigate such complaints. The Assistant Secretary will investigate complaints of non-compliance with bullying policies in local educational agencies and take actions such as withholding funds, issuing cease and desist orders, or entering into compliance agreements to ensure compliance with the law. The Assistant Secretary can take actions like withholding funds, issuing cease and desist orders, or entering into compliance agreements to address non-compliance with bullying policies in local educational agencies. The Department of Education must provide information on its website about complaints of bullying, including details of protected characteristics if relevant, while excluding student's personal information. Bullying is defined as severe, pervasive acts causing harm or concern towards a student during school hours or activities. Bullying is defined as a physical act causing harm or concern towards a student during school hours or activities, leading to withdrawal or avoidance of school services. Protected characteristics include race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation.
